ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

JOBS FOR RESIDENT WORKFORCE


    1. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Acting Minister for Manpower (a) if he will explain (i) how the 9 in 10 jobs going to resident workforce is derived, (ii) whether there is any difference in this ratio across

Column: 2350

the various major sectors of the economy, and (iii) how has this ratio changed since 1996; and (b) will the Government consider introducing measures such as those in the US, where an employer can hire a foreigner only after he has failed in his attempt to employ a local.

    2. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Acting Minister for Manpower in view of his comments in the press, if he will (i) clarify his comments that foreign workers are being used to moderate the wages of Singaporean workers; (ii) state what are the 'other national objectives' that he is referring to; (iii) explain how will the release of specific employment data compromise our national interest and these objectives; and (iv) release the statistics to substantiate the claims of his Ministry that 9 out of 10 jobs created in the last 5 years went to Singaporeans.

    The Acting Minister for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I propose to take Question Nos 1 and 2 after Question Time in the form of a Ministerial Statement. This is to allow other questions to be answered as well as to allow ample time for Members to ask questions after my reply.

    Mr Speaker: All right. We will proceed to the other Questions then.

Column: 2350

STANDARD OF LIVING


    The following Question stood in the name of Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong -

    3. To ask the Minister for Trade and Industry whether (i) the ongoing wage reform and wage cuts will mean that Singaporeans will see their standard of living going down over the next few years, and (ii) the Government is taking active measures to keep the cost of living down.

    Mr Charles Chong (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Question No. 3, Sir.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, our standard of living in Singapore will have to adjust to a level which makes

Column: 2351

our companies and our economy competitive. Wages in Singapore are currently under pressure because of cyclical and structural reasons.

    On the cyclical front, the weakness of the global economy and SARS have led to the poor performance of our economy since 2001. The second quarter of this year was particularly bad, aggravated by the uncertainty of the Iraqi War. However, with the war over and SARS behind us, for the time being at least, our economy is likely to be better in the second half. The US economy is also showing signs of recovery with a better than expected 2.4% growth in the second quarter. Many analysts believe that US growth in the second half could be even stronger. Our forecast of 0 - 1% growth for this year implies that we expect our economy to grow by 1.3 - 3.3% in the second half of the year, compared to a contraction of 1.3% in the first half.

    While our economy may improve in the coming months, we face serious longer-term structural challenges. The entry of China, India, Vietnam and other countries into the global market place means that the wages of many workers in Singapore will come under strong downward pressure. This pressure is across the board because of the large number of skilled workers, technicians, engineers, programmers and others from these countries who are prepared to do the same work for much less money. Outsourcing has resulted in an increasingly globalised labour market.

    However, skill for skill, job for job, our workers and professionals do command a significant premium over their competitors in other countries because of our reputation for quality and reliability, and the efficiency and integrity of the system that we have. The Singapore reputation enhances the value of all Singaporeans in the global marketplace. Hence, we continue to attract large investments in the manufacturing sectors like electronics, engineering, petrochemicals and the biomedical sciences, and in the services sectors like the financial industry, tourism and logistics.

Column: 2352



    But this Singapore premium is finite. Beyond a point, we are not worth the premium and, if our wages are too high, the investments will flow elsewhere instead, as indeed is already happening in some sectors. It is therefore very important for us to watch our costs, labour being a key component of total cost. We have to make our wage structure more flexible. It has to be more performance-based (less seniority-based), and more responsive to changes in business conditions. The way to reduce adjustment pains is to allow for frequent adjustments in our wage structure and, more importantly, in our thinking. This is the way for us to maintain our competitiveness and safeguard our jobs in a rapidly changing global economy. If we do not adjust our standard of living to stay competitive, the market will force it on us in a more painful way through the outflow of investment and retrenchment.

    On the cost of living in Singapore, it has remained relatively stable in recent years. Between 1997 - 2002, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) has risen by only 0.6% per year, and in fact fell 0.4% last year. The Government monitors this index closely.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Sir, with the wage reforms that are on-going, the basic pay of our workers will be cut. Is MTI monitoring how this might affect those with huge commitments in housing, children's education and car loans?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Various Government agencies are looking at how some of these adjustments can be made less painful. The Government will always make sure that every citizen has a shelter over his head, there is adequate basic health care and the education of the young is properly looked after. But beyond that, adjustments will be necessary and some of them will be painful.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong: Sir, while it is true that cost of living has been quite stable, Singaporeans feel that certain components of it need to be monitored more closely, such as transport. I wonder whether the Minister would consider

Column: 2353

setting up a committee just to look at how we can bring transport costs down.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, I believe we already have mechanisms to monitor the changes in transport costs to ensure that they are reasonable, justified and affordable.

Column: 2353

UNEMPLOYED SINGAPOREANS


    4. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Trade and Industry with the hope of foreign investments flowing to Singapore's manufacturing and services sector and creating between 12,000 and 15,000 new jobs (a) how and in what form will the economic restructuring be; (b) how will jobless Singaporeans be trained and assisted for gainful employment opportunities in these newly created jobs; (c) what will be the likely duration for the Singaporean unemployed to be ready for such gainful employment opportunities in these newly created jobs; (d) of the unemployed, how many constitute those released from prisons and drug rehabilitation centres; (e) how are these unemployed ex-criminals and drug offenders being assisted to gain employment without being prejudiced by employers.

    The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, Mdm Ho Geok Choo has asked a somewhat comprehensive Question which covers three Ministries - mine, the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Ministry of Manpower. I have been given the privilege to give the initial response to her.

    On economic restructuring, with rising competition and technological changes, we need to restructure our economy in two main ways. First, we need to shift towards a more flexible and competitive cost structure. This means reforming our wage structure to be more responsive to changes in business conditions, and re-tuning our CPF system to reduce statutory burden on employers. We must also

Column: 2354

lower direct taxes, and price our land and other infrastructure services competitively.

    Second, we need to shift towards higher value-added, knowledge-based activities. This means moving up the manufacturing value chain, growing exportable services, and upgrading our domestic services sector. Of the 12,000 to 15,000 new jobs that EDB will bring in this year, more than 85% will require skilled workers. We must therefore upgrade the capabilities of our work force, and re-skill our workers.

    Next, I will turn to assistance and training for unemployed Singaporeans. Under its Place and Train programme, the Manpower Ministry works with industry partners to first place job seekers with a prospective employer, before sending them for training. This is better than the train-then-place approach as it minimises wastage in training. MOM will work with EDB and employers to match job seekers with new jobs created, and provide the necessary training to equip them with the right skills and knowledge. Payroll-support for training will be provided through the Skills Redevelopment Fund (SRF).

    Finally, on employment and rehabilitation of ex-criminals, we do not track the proportion of unemployed who are ex-prisoners or released from Drug Rehabilitation Centres (DRCs). Every year, there are about 11,000 offenders released from prisons and DRCs. In the first six months of this year, more than 900 ex-offenders have approached the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) to seek assistance in securing jobs. Of these, 39% were successfully placed in gainful employment.

    Offenders are prepared for gainful employment while they are still in prison and DRCs. SCORE provides them with vocational training in various skills such as food preparation, metal work and electronics. Employers also participate in training sponsorship and offering jobs. In 2001, the Prisons Department embarked on a public education campaign to counter prejudices in employing ex-offenders. Earlier this

Column: 2355

year, SCORE and a local company produced a movie `Twilight Kitchen' which traces the struggle of an ex-offender trying to gain acceptance at his work place. The movie will be screened to grassroots organisations to create greater awareness on the role that the community can play in reintegrating ex-offenders.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, in view of our economic restructuring, how do we intend to actually grow those sectors that will be our cash cows? As for those sectors that we would not be doing well in, what are our plans going forward? Would we be eliminating these sectors and, if so, how should we relocate employees in these sectors?

    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: There are three key thrusts in the strategy going ahead. One is that we intend to expand our external ties and that is why we have the free trade agreements and the informal people networks that we have launched. This is one of the key thrusts, which is basically to have a globalised economy.

    The second thrust is to create an entrepreneurial economy and this is to create Singapore as a source of enterprise itself - a market for talents, ideas and capital. Finally, a diversified economy that, besides manufacturing, the other pillar of growth will be services and we will expand these services not just to strengthen our traditional areas of strength like logistics, finance or tourism but in new areas, such as healthcare, education and the creative industries.

    This is the broad strategy. How it actually shapes up, I think we will have to let the market decide, including the movement of labour and people into the different industries.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Can I just ask the Minister whether he thinks that Singapore can effectively compete in the manufacturing sector in the coming years in the light of the competition that we face from India and, particularly, China, with their cheaper source of labour?

Column: 2356



    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: I am quite confident that we will be able to compete. What is important is that we ensure that the economy as a whole is cost-competitive and what is important in terms of competition for the investment dollar is really the total package. It is not just a question of absolute cost but, at the end of the day, it is really output per unit of cost that is important. It is for this reason that Singapore has managed to continue to hold its own in the contest for the investment dollar. Last year, we brought in about $9 billion in fixed asset manufacturing investment. This year, as the Prime Minister has announced in his National Day message, we are looking at about $7.5 billion. We will continue to get major investments into Singapore. So I think it is the totality. Cost is an important factor but there are other attributes that bring investments into Singapore.

Column: 2356

ASSISTANCE SCHEMES FOR LOCAL ENTERPRISES
(Reduction of grants)


    5. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what are the reasons for reducing the various grants such as Local Enterprise Technical Assistance Scheme (LETAS), Local Enterprise Finance Scheme (LEFS) and Micro Loan Programme (MLP) when the need for such schemes is even more pressing in view of our present economic climate.

    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Sir, SPRING Singapore reviews and calibrates its various SME assistance schemes from time to time to ensure optimal use and effectiveness. The Government's co-funding share for LETAS was raised from 50% to 70% for first-time applicants in October 1999, and for the National Cost of Quality and Financial Advisor programmes in November 2001. The intent was to promote awareness of SMEs on LETAS and these two programmes. As the objective has since been met - for instance, the number of first-time applicants for LETAS doubled from 1,500 in FY 1999 to 3,000 in FY 2002 - the co-funding share for these categories has

Column: 2357

reverted to the normal 50% in July 2003. This will allow the pool of LETAS funds to support more SME upgrading and new programmes.

    Other than these modifications to LETAS, there are no changes to either the Local Enterprise Finance Scheme (LEFS) or the Micro Loan Programme. In fact, during this economic slowdown, LEFS has been enhanced twice, in November 2001 and June 2003, and both in terms of moving it up so that more medium enterprises, and down to the smaller companies, would qualify for LEFS. I wish to assure Dr Neo that the Government is aware of the importance of helping SMEs in these challenging times. We are in fact looking into expanding the Loan Insurance Scheme (LIS) and the Bridging Loan Programme to benefit more SMEs. Details will be announced when ready.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): May I ask the Minister of State whether reducing the quantum for LETAS in fact runs counter to the bigger picture of the need to revive our economy and to increase entrepreneurship? Should there not be priority given to assist local businesses, with concerted efforts by various Ministries, rather than cutting back?

    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: LETAS was, right from the start, a co-funding scheme, and it was 50% by the Government and 50% by the company itself. This is to ensure commitment. As I have explained, the reason why we went up to 70% was for a particular period of time, which is promotional. The issue here is really to get SMEs to upgrade their capabilities.

    The other issue that the hon. Member brought up is really a matter of how best to help SMEs when it comes to cash-flow financing. That is the difficulty we have in an economic downturn - not just a question of upgrading capabilities, but how do we help them so that a liquidity problem does not turn into an insolvency problem. And here there is actually a whole range of schemes that has been

Column: 2358

launched by the Government and which is still in existence. As I said, LEFS is one scheme where you can actually tap on it for working capital. The Micro Loan Scheme actually helps very small companies to tide over difficult periods where they are tight in their cash flow.

    The Bridging Loan Programme, which was introduced during the SARS outbreak and which is still in operation, seeks again to help companies who are particularly badly affected during the SARS outbreak in terms of their cashflow requirements. So there is a whole range of schemes.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister of State whether his Ministry has been stringent in approving applications under the various schemes, such as LETAS, LEFS and MLP? What are the approval rates for such schemes? Is there too much red tape associated with these schemes? Am I correct to say that LETAS application is cumbersome, requiring a lot of information and difficult ones, such as the impact of the project on the company's future operations and business?

    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: Actually that is not a difficult question. If I were to give you money, I would like to know what are your company's plans.

    Is the Government too stringent in approving applications under LEFS, LETAS and MLP? I think our philosophy must be that at the end of the day to use market mechanism to decide, because funds are finite and we will have to find a way to allocate the funds to those who are most deserving of help. The way we have gone around is basically to use financial players who are already in the industry, rather than for the Government to substitute itself for the financial players. So, in the case of LEFS, for instance, we have 17 participating financial institutions.

    How does the Government help? The Government helps by providing the credit line. The problem for SMEs is the perception by industry players that the risks are higher. By providing the credit line, the Government is actually lowering the risks for the financial player that is actually

Column: 2359

awarding a particular loan. So, the Government takes 80% of the risks and the financial industry player takes 20%.

    The other issue here is in terms of expertise. Does the particular financial institution understand the SME business well enough in order to assess it and give out the loan? Increasingly, the market will have players that specialise in SMEs financing. For instance, recently, OCBC Bank has announced that it is going into partnership with Hong Kong SME Loan, which specialises in cash-flow lending, which is important for SMEs. Hong Leong Finance is also positioning itself as a SME bank to help them. So, that must be the approach. The Government should not substitute itself for existing financial players, because that would be crowding them out.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): Sir, I think the Minister of State missed the point that Dr Neo was trying to get at. Is it not possible to simplify the procedures when applying for such grants? One of the most common complaints among the SMEs when applying for the grants under the schemes is the number of forms and questions that they have to answer, bearing in mind that many of these companies do not have professional backup.

    The second question I would like to pose is that in submitting their business plans, many of these SMEs have to engage consultants. I understand that previously the consultancy fees were heavily subsidised. Am I right to say that the consultancy fees are no longer subsidised, or has the subsidy been significantly reduced and, if so, why?

    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: The short answer to the question whether or not there is too much administrative hassle in applying for a loan is that if that is the case, give me the details and we will look into them. Our aim is to facilitate. The fact of the matter is that there have been a lot of loans that have been approved. But if, at the margin, there are excessive rules that you think we can cut down, the answer is yes, we will look into them.

Column: 2360



    On the point of the consultancy fees, there is still subsidy for the consultancy fees. As to the actual quantum, I do not have the details here, but I could give them to the hon. Member separately.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister of State whether these various schemes are well publicised and targeted at those who may benefit most, and whether he would consider promoting these schemes further to increase their take-up rate so that we can help more SMEs?

    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: The schemes are actually pretty well publicised. All the chambers of commerce, for instance, are fully aware of these schemes; business associations, whether it be the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, the chambers of commerce - we actually have satellite centres in some of these chambers of commerce to try to promote these schemes, so that they have a better understanding of the schemes. If the Member feels that more can be done, let us know and we will see how best to do so.

Column: 2360

RETRENCHED AND UNEMPLOYED HOME-OWNERS
(Interim financial assistance schemes)


    6. Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Minister for Community Development and Sports if there are any interim financial assistance schemes available to the recently retrenched or unemployed home-owners to sustain them for a longer period as they use up their savings.

    The Minister for Community Development and Sports (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim): Mr Speaker, Sir, Ms Braema will be pleased to know that we have schemes in place to help the retrenched or unemployed workers, particularly those from the lower income group.

    One such scheme is the Interim Short-term Financial Assistance Scheme (IFAS) that provides temporary relief to tide the families over a difficult period, such as a crisis or unemployment. This scheme

Column: 2361

is currently administered by the Community Development Councils. Assistance is given for three months in the first instance, and may be renewed for another three months should the family circumstances justify further assistance. IFAS has also helped families in purchased flats who face temporary difficulties in paying for their current utilities and conservancy charges. There is also help given to schooling children for their school expenses. This is over and above what the schools provide. In financial year 2002, about 6,700 cases were approved for short-term assistance.

    Apart from the above, the Citizens' Consultative Committees (CCCs) do offer assistance to residents who are facing financial hardship. Food rations, bursaries and, in some cases, direct financial assistance, have been given by CCCs to residents in need.

    In addition, there are also several financial assistance measures to help HDB mortgagors who face financial hardship arising from a reduction or loss of income due to wage cuts, retrenchment or business failure. These include:

    1) Conversion to a reduced repayment scheme, under which a mortgagor can pay between 50% and 75% of the normal loan instalment;

    2) Deferment of payment of loan instalments for six months;

    3) Extension of loan repayment period;

    Clause 3 of the Bill seeks to amend section 20 of the Enlistment Act by inserting, immediately after subsection (3), new subsections (4), (5) and (6), to provide that a regular serviceman who is sentenced by a subordinate military court to be "discharged with ignominy" or "dismissed", shall be deemed to be discharged from regular service from the date of the sentence or any date as may be specified by the subordinate military court.
